case_vignette: A 68-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of difficulty in breathing for the past 2 days. He has had recurrent episodes of bacterial pneumonia in the right lower lobe during the last 6 months. His last episode of pneumonia started 7 days ago for which he is being treated with antibiotics. He has a 35-pack-year smoking history. Past medical history is significant for hypertension for which he takes lisinopril. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion in the right lung base. Chest X-ray reveals a large right-sided pleural effusion, and chest CT scan shows a large mass near the hilum of the right lung. Cytologic examination of pleural fluid shows evidence of malignancy.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
